items.title: Replacing in xml string extracted from `_element.xml`
items.body:
Hi, I have a .docx file which has few template tags(django, jinja) which I want to use.  Unfortunately when I see the xml I see between the tags some junk is often seen. I got a regex by which I can filter out the junk.


Can you see the junk between {{ }}? The tags were put simply like  {{SOMETHING}} or {{SOMETHING|to_upper}} in the docx but when the xml is seen it inserts garbage between the tags.
This nice package https://docxtpl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/   also fails to handle such cases and gives error which is my next task to use after cleaning the junk.

Can someone help in how can I make replacements in document._element.xml(which is a class) and then save a docx file with that xml? 

    **`document._element.xml = remove_junk(document._element.xml) #gives AttributeError  can't assign`**
```


  <w:t>{{</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:proofErr w:type="spellStart"/>
            <w:r>
              <w:rPr>
                <w:rFonts w:ascii="Times New Roman" w:hAnsi="Times New Roman" w:cs="Times New Roman"/>
                <w:sz w:val="15"/>
                <w:szCs w:val="15"/>
                <w:lang w:val="en-IN" w:eastAsia="en-IN"/>
              </w:rPr>
              <w:t>HOL|to_words</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:proofErr w:type="spellEnd"/>
            <w:r>
              <w:rPr>
                <w:rFonts w:ascii="Times New Roman" w:hAnsi="Times New Roman" w:cs="Times New Roman"/>
                <w:sz w:val="15"/>
                <w:szCs w:val="15"/>
                <w:lang w:val="en-IN" w:eastAsia="en-IN"/>
              </w:rPr>
              <w:t>}}</w:t>

        
```
whereas the actual  text that I put in word was   {{HOL|to_words}}. I don't know how these big chunks of junks get inserted in between.

Code
```

def remove_junk(test_str):
    regex = r"{{(?:(?!}}).)*?<w:t>([^<]+)<\/w:t>(?:(?!}}).)*?}}"
    subst = "{{\\1}}"

    # You can manually specify the number of replacements by changing the 4th argument
    result = re.sub(regex, subst, test_str, 0, re.DOTALL)

    return result

for i in sys.argv[1:]:
    filename = os.path.splitext(Path(i).name)[0]
    document = Document(i)
    document._element.xml = remove_junk(document._element.xml) #gives AttributeError  can't assign
    
    document.save(os.path.splitext(i)[0]+"_new.docx")

```

items.title: Understanding insert_element_before
items.body:
Without going in all details, I am currently trying to create a template for reporting which contains all the tables, paragraphs, sections, and (empty) pictures which will be read by python-docx. Now, I will - for a start - copy a paragraph from one location to another. Thus, for instance, create a paragraph after (or before) another using all the content and style of the one in action.

So, I read a lot and tried to understand lxml, etree, and of course python-xml.
Where I ended up was this little function

```
def copy_before_paragraph(p,insert):
    """
    Return a newly created paragraph, inserted directly before this
    paragraph using the template from "insert"
    """
    templ = deepcopy(insert)
    newp = p._p.insert_element_before(templ)
    return Paragraph(newp, p._parent)

p13=mydoc.paragraphs[13]
p14=mydoc.paragraphs[14]
copy_before_paragraph(p13,p14._p)
```

which works - somewhat - and not at the same time.
Looking at the result, the content of p14 is added *after* p13 and it is in the same paragraph!
So, looking at the xml of p13 I see:

```
<w:p xmlns:w=....>
  <w:pPr>
    ...
  </w:pPr>
  <w:r>
    ... text of p13
  </w:r>
  <w:p w:rsidR="00FF4FE6" w:rsidRDefault="00FF4FE6" w:rsidP="00FF4FE6">
    ... content of p14
  </w:p>
</w:p>
```

Interestingly this works, but it is obviously wrong.
So, how can I really add before the paragraph p13 in the way I want to do that?

Any help very appreciated.

And of course: great package! Thanks

items.title: Cell merging is slow
items.body:
i have been merging cells row wise in multiple table and it takes about 1 second to merge a row containing 20 cells using this "row.cells[0].merge(row.cells[-1])". i am merging upto 50 rows in whole doc. which makes it upto 1 min . is there any faster way? 
here are some functions i am using. 
calling text_rows funtion 5 times  with count =10 in whole process. like so

` text_rows(table,10)`

```python
def insert_rows_for_data(table, row_count):
    strt_point = len(table.rows)
    col_count = len(table.columns)
    for i in range(row_count):
        table.add_row()

    table_cells = table._cells
    return strt_point, col_count, table_cells


def text_rows(table, count, text=None, align=True, color=None):
    starting, col_count, table_cells = insert_rows_for_data(table, count)
    for index, x in enumerate(range(count)):
        empty_row = table_cells[starting * col_count : (starting + 1) * col_count]
        empty_row[0].merge(empty_row[-1])
        if text:
            empty_row[0].text = text
        if align == True:
            align_cell(empty_row[0])
        if color:
            add_custom_color(empty_row[0], color)
        starting += 1
```

items.title: Changing Heading font doesn't work
items.body:
https://python-docx.readthedocs.io/en/latest/user/styles-using.html implies that I should be able to change Heading font styles like this:
```
font = doc.styles['Heading 1'].font
font.name = 'Times New Roman'
font.size = docx.shared.Pt(16)
```
But that doesn't work: the resulting document uses Calibri for all headings. (They're also blue and Heading 1 has an underline, which I also need to eliminate somehow.)

It also doesn't work to change the font on a specific heading, nor to delete the latent_styles for the headings.

Github won't let me attach a .py file, so here's my sample standalone program that tries all three methods, but all of the headings come out as blue Calibri despite all attempts to change them to Times New Roman. 

```
#!/usr/bin/env python3

import docx

doc = docx.Document()

# Deleting heading latent styles seems to do nothing:
latent_styles = doc.styles.latent_styles
latent_styles['Heading 1'].delete()
latent_styles['Heading 2'].delete()

# Setting the Normal font works:
font = doc.styles['Normal'].font
font.name = 'Times New Roman'
font.size = docx.shared.Pt(12)

# Setting heading styles doesn't do anything:
# they all still end up as blue Calibri.
font = doc.styles['Heading 1'].font
font.name = 'Times New Roman'
font.size = docx.shared.Pt(16)

font = doc.styles['Heading 2'].font
font.name = 'Times New Roman'
font.size = docx.shared.Pt(14)

doc.add_heading("Heading 0", 0)
doc.add_paragraph('Here is a paragraph of text.')
doc.add_heading("Heading 1", 1)
doc.add_paragraph('Here is a paragraph of text.')
doc.add_heading("Heading 2", 2)
doc.add_paragraph('Here is a paragraph of text.')

# It also doesn't work to change the style of a specific heading:
heading = doc.add_heading("Another Heading 1", 1)
heading.style.font.name = "Times New Roman"
doc.add_paragraph('Here is a paragraph of text.')

doc.save('/tmp/test.docx')
```

The document produced:
[test.docx](https://github.com/python-openxml/python-docx/files/4399175/test.docx)

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/37220754/cant-change-heading-1-font-name-using-docx mentions this as a known bug, but the only issues I found here were 390 which seems to be dismissed as an Asian font issue, and 366, I'm not sure if that's the same problem or not.

items.title: Feature: add_table() before and after parameter
items.body:
This is similar to #793 but for tables.

I suggest to define table creation as follows:

```python
def add_table(self, rows, cols, style=None, before=None, after=None):
```

where both `before` and `after` parameters will accept `Paragraph` instance of paragraph the table is inserting, `before` in case table is inserting before the paragraph in `before`, and similarly for `after`.

If both `before` and `after` parameters are provided, some exception should be raised.

items.title: Feature: add_paragraph() before and after parameter
items.body:
Hi, I am aware of `insert_paragraph_before()`.

I hope that one simple method is better then different specific methods, so I suggest to define it like:

```python
def add_paragraph(self, text='', style=None, before=None, after=None):
```

If `before` is provided, it will do same as `insert_paragraph_before()`, if `after` is provided, it will add paragraph after existing one, provided in `after` parameter.

If both `before` and `after` are provided some exception will be raised.

```python
      author = t.cell(index,3).text
      if (len(version) != 0) and (len(datetime) != 0) and (len(modifyContent) != 0) and (len(author) != 0):            
          return f.decode(encoding='gbk') + '\n' + version + '   ' + datetime + '   ' + modifyContent + '   ' + author  + '\n'
          break
  
if __name__ == "__main__":
  PATH = os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__)) 
  doc_files = os.listdir(PATH)
  for doc in doc_files:
    if os.path.splitext(doc)[1] == '.docx':
      try:
        retstr = parse_docx(PATH+'\\'+doc)
        print retstr
      except Exception as e:
        print e
```

The output obtained after executing the script is “V0.0.3   2014-01-22   Modify 2   Test3”，that's not the data I expected to get.

items.title: python-docx destroys {PAGE} and {NUMPAGES} fields in header and footer during manipulation
items.body:
This is a great tool for automatically generating documents. I have read that it doesn't handle automated page numbering, because that is something that is rendered at runtime, but I've been trying to figure out a way to work around that.

I've used the following to create an empty template:

`from docx import Document`
`import re`
`document = Document()`
`paragraph = document.add_paragraph('Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet.')`
`section = document.sections[0]`
`footer=section.footer`
`paragraph = footer.paragraphs[0]`
`paragraph.text = "Hopefully this is a footer"`
`out='./outputs/test.docx'`
`document.save(out)`

and the test.docx file it creates is attached. I then mod the file in word, by going in and manually adding a 'Page X of Y' field in the footer, test_modded.docx, also attached.

[test.docx](https://github.com/python-openxml/python-docx/files/3301919/test.docx)
[test_modded.docx](https://github.com/python-openxml/python-docx/files/3301921/test_modded.docx)

My thinking is that while python-docs doesn't know about the page numbering fields, I could perhaps use the modded document as a template and do a search and replace on the text component, to check whether the page numbering fields can survive being passed through python-docx.

`moddeddocument = Document('./outputs/test_modded.docx')`
`section = moddeddocument.sections[0]`
`footer=section.footer`
`paragraph = footer.paragraphs[0]`
`paragraph.text=paragraph.text.replace("Hopefully", "Thankfully")`
`moddeddocument.save('./outputs/test_modded_out.docx')`

[test_modded_out.docx](https://github.com/python-openxml/python-docx/files/3301945/test_modded_out.docx)

Unfortunately, these fields don't survive, and get flatted to ASCII.

It seems like the act of evaluating parargaph.text is what destroys the control codes I want to preserve.
Any thoughts on how I might preserve them under the kind of operation I describe above?

Thanks,

Jeff.

File Name: /docx/parts/image.py
Line Number: 168
Info: This function uses the hashlib.sha1() function, which uses a hash algorithm that is considered weak. In recent years, researchers have demonstrated ways to breach many uses of previously-thought-safe hash functions such as MD5.
 
Consider using a stronger algorithm in order to prevent attackers from being able to manipulate hash results. If this algorithm is being used to hash passwords, then consider using a strong computationally-hard algorithm such as PBKDF2 or bcrypt instead of a plain hashing algorithm.
